div.p: The (00 1) CdTe surface has been extensively investigated by grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (GIXD) [l] and STM [2'3]. Lett. . X-ray diffraction was used to investigate in-situ the Ar + ion sputtering of the CdTe(OOl) surface. The correlation lengths on the surface were estimated from the widths along the h and k directions of an integer order reflection close to anti-Bragg condition (at 1 =0) to be about 400 ~ (evaluated as L = as /Ah(Ak)). The (1 20. 1) reflection intensity (close to the out-of-phase condition) was used to follow the roughness evolution during the removal which is characteristic of a layer-by-layer behaviour at substrate temperatures below 280°C and of an almost step flow above 300°C. The evolution of the de-growth mode from a layerby-layer to an almost step-flow can be understood considering the high mobility of the Cd and Te atoms at ' 5] The more surprising result, however, appears in the diffraction peak profiles these temperatures . recorded along the h ([1 -1 O]) and k ([1 1 O]) directions (Fig. 1-a , b). The sample temperature was kept constant at 270°C during the sputtering and the peak profile measurements were performed after quenching the system by simultaneously stopping the ion gun and the sample heater after removal of a given coverage. A very different behaviour is observed along the h and k directions. A broad peak at 0.016 reciprocal lattice units (r. 100 ~ was determined. To understand these findings it is necessary to take into account the surface energy minimisation during the sputtering and to consider the microscopic structure of the CdTe(001) surface. The c(2x2) structure is formed by 0.5 ML of Cd atoms bounded to a full Te layer and arranged such that a strong lattice distortion is produced in the CdTe bulk structure down to the 6th atomic layer inwards [l] . The heating of this surface under UHV above 280°C produces a structural transition to a 2x1 surface which is supposed to have the same atomic pattern as the c(2X2) [3] . However the 2x1 symmetry does not allow the bond rotation around the Cd atoms in the third layer which is, in the c(2x2) structure, essential for strain propagation.
